Spring Vacation
WHILE WE hold no brief for the ad- Do?
ministration so far as defending its polio—o
cies is concerned, yet

it seems to us that
the writer of the letter appearing in our
column today is being rather unjust in
his broad statement that the students receive little consideration from the administration. Dr. Ames, in explaining why
the spring vacation is set for the last
week in March instead of coinciding with
Easter week, stated that this has been
done in order to divide evenly for the
student the burden of his second semester
work. Apparently, every effort is being
made to give us a break.
Dr. Ames said further that other universities throughout the country are inaugurating the same plan.

Brilliant of conception and magnificent of scope, Calvalcade, the
mighty story of a mighty nation,
swings triumphantly into its second
week at the Maryland Theatre Monday.
Perhaps the finest, by far the
most dramatic, offering ever to emanate from the skilled pen of Noel
Coward, that international exponent of the finest of the playwright's
art, Cavalcade is truly the production of the century.
More than thirty of the most
stirring years in the history of the
British Empire pass in stately and
breath-taking review, as the simple
plot which forms the background
for this great drama weaves its pattern down the years.

LETTERS TO
THE EDITOR

Time and again, Bell System engineers have
demonstrated their pioneering bent in working out
unusual telephone construction problems.
For example, they laid a huge conduit under the
Harlem River. They dredged a trench in the river
bottom, lowered enormous sections of iron pipe,
sent down divers to join the sections, encased the
finished tube in concrete. Through this they ran
telephone cables forming one of New York's main
lines of communication. Across the Gila River in
Arizona they constructed a catenary span 2373 feet
long. To bridge oceans, they developed radio telephony. They have built telephone lines over mountains, across deserts, through swamps.
Their resourcefulness in getting through, over or
under natural barriers makes possible telephone service that is practically world wide in reach.

BELL SYSTEM

University, the spring vacation has been
definitely set for the last week in March.
It seems to me that this innovation is
entirely detrimental to the student body.
In the past, the administrators of the
University have acted without giving serious thought to the desires of the students. This change is another of these
dictatorial acts. I am fairly certain that
the student body would much prefer to
have their vacation during Easter.
The administration has stated that the
reason for this change was to have the
second semester of the year divided into
two equal halves. They have said that
this would make the task of teaching a
course easier, as the instructor would not
have to revise his schedule to fit the
current date of Easter. Although I am
taking six courses, I must say that in
none of these does the date of Easter
have any effect upon the teaching of the
course.
The administration has also stated that
since we finish the scholastic year at a
very early date, we should have our
spring vacation as soon as possible. Although Columbia University starts its
summer vacation a full two weeks before
we do, it has its spring holiday during
Easter.
I think that the University would do
well to consider the desire of the students
as well as the whims of the faculty members when they are considering matters
of great importance to the student body.
A JUNIOR.

22 MEN OF 1932

SQUAD RETURNED
Practice Will Be Held Regularly During Spring
Vacation
The 1933 conception of the old
Indian game, lacrosse, will make its
debut here on Saturday, April 8,
when the Johns Hopkins lacrosse
team, 1932 Olympic champion, inaugurates its current season against
Washington College at Homewood
field.
Lacrosse, this year, will be played
on a field 30 yards shorter than last
season's and with teams of 10 men
instead of the usual 12 which engaged in the game previous to this
year. For this reason, the Black
and Blue practice sessions for the
past two weeks have been in the
nature of an experiment to determine what type of play will give the
strongest game in compliance with
the new rules.
Coach Working New Plays

Coach Van Orman and his staff,
feeling that many new angles of the
game will turn up from practical
experience in contests, plan intensive
drills so that all phases of the game
can be thoroughly tested and the
Hopkins stickmen instructed in
overcoming any handicaps that may
arise from the rules changes.
Twenty-two members of last
year's squad are out to make the
Blue Jay team again this year, in
addition to many promising freshmen. Because of this wealth of material available for the team, the
coaches plan to drill two full teams
into shape, which will share action
in the games.

Manager Harold Stein
made the announcement that he
has added Swarthmore and Duke
to the tennis team's schedule.
Swarthmore will be played away
April 13th and Duke will be encountered at Homewood May 4th.
This completes the campaign, which
includes 16 matches with many of
the strongest teams in the east.
Lindsay Helmholtz, a student in
the grad school, who has been a
member of the varsity tennis team
for the last 3 years, will assist Dr.
Silverman in coaching the team.

Denouncing the attitude of Republicans, Democrats and Socialists
on the question of race prejudice,
Emmet May, colored graduate of
Shaw College and Tennessee educator, last week presented his point
of view on the "Negro Question"
before members of the National
Student League.
May dramatically described in
his speech the story of the lynching of an innocent boy by an angry
mob of citizens in a southern town
where he was teaching. He said that
he was acquainted with the boy and
knew that the charges against him
had been "trumped up."

holiday. He declared that both
state and national bank authorities
had been too lax in granting licenses to new banks. Accordingly,
banks had grown up which possessed no adequate capital or reserves, which were run by inexperienced and dishonest men and
which engaged in speculation and
unsound banking practices. When
the public lost confidence in these
banks, and the inevitable runs
started, the majority of such banking institutions could not meet the
demands of their depositors and
finally, to prevent the failure of
vast numbers of banks, a holiday
was declared.
From this experience, the banker
said, certain things have become
clear. First, the small "crossroads"
bank must go; second, all banks
should be brought under the Federal Reserve System; third, the supervision of these banks must
become more strict. He stated that
banks should fulfill only one main
function: that of keeping their depositors' money safe and available;
and all other activities, especially
those of a speculative nature, should
be forbidden. Strict reserve requirements should be set up, higher
than those today, and banks failing
to fulfill such requirements should
be fined or closed. The assets of all

ILLUSION:
A large packing case is exhibited on a raised platform. A young woman climbs into the box. Head,
hands and feet protrude, and are held by spectators while the magician takes a crosscut saw and,
with the help of an assistant, saws through the
center of the box and apparently through the woman.

EXPLANATION:
There are many explanations for this illusion. One
method of performing this illusion requires the
presence of two girls in the box. One girl curls up
in the left half of the box with her head and hands
protruding, giving the effect you see illustrated
above. The other girl is doubled up in the right
half of the box, with only her feet showing. Nobody
is sawed in half.

Travelling Actor,
Makes Clever Cut

Max Montor, On Carl Schurz
Foundation, Gives Masterpiece From Memory
Through the courtesy of the Carl
SchurzMemorial Foundation Hop-kins was favored with a Faust recitation by Max Montor last Monday
at Levering. Montor, a well known
German actor, is now traveling in
this country, reciting masterpieces
of the German and English stage.
His "Faust, Part One," which he
gave entirely from memory was very
ingeniously cut, reducing the enormous play to the extent of an hour
and a half, thus bringing out the
action very clearly. The Hall was
well filled with about 200 people
from Hopkins as well as from town,
who enjoyed the masterly rendering
of Goethe's greatest work.

Spring Vacation
WHILE WE hold no brief for the ad- Do?
ministration so far as defending its polio—o
cies is concerned, yet

it seems to us that
the writer of the letter appearing in our
column today is being rather unjust in
his broad statement that the students receive little consideration from the administration. Dr. Ames, in explaining why
the spring vacation is set for the last
week in March instead of coinciding with
Easter week, stated that this has been
done in order to divide evenly for the
student the burden of his second semester
work. Apparently, every effort is being
made to give us a break.
Dr. Ames said further that other universities throughout the country are inaugurating the same plan.

Brilliant of conception and magnificent of scope, Calvalcade, the
mighty story of a mighty nation,
swings triumphantly into its second
week at the Maryland Theatre Monday.
Perhaps the finest, by far the
most dramatic, offering ever to emanate from the skilled pen of Noel
Coward, that international exponent of the finest of the playwright's
art, Cavalcade is truly the production of the century.
More than thirty of the most
stirring years in the history of the
British Empire pass in stately and
breath-taking review, as the simple
plot which forms the background
for this great drama weaves its pattern down the years.

In keeping with their policy of
showing the finest of the current
first-run pictures during short periods through the week, the Little
Theatre (formerly the Europa) offers for the vacation season a topnotch list of hit attractions which
should entice the most particular.
Following a return showing of
Josef von Sternberg's success,
Shanghai Express, which will be
concluded Sunday, the week will
commence with Alfred Lunt and
Lynn Fontanne's witty and sophisticated social comedy, The Guardsman.
Mata Hari, finest vehicle of the
great Garbo, will conclude their
second week under this new system.
Horror And How!

When a truly thrilling and truly
well done horror picture is made it
will ever have its followers. King
Kong is both truly thrilling and well
done, and so great have been the
acclamations of its audience that the
Hippodrome has found it necessary
to hold this fantasy of the land of

LETTERS TO
THE EDITOR

Time and again, Bell System engineers have
demonstrated their pioneering bent in working out
unusual telephone construction problems.
For example, they laid a huge conduit under the
Harlem River. They dredged a trench in the river
bottom, lowered enormous sections of iron pipe,
sent down divers to join the sections, encased the
finished tube in concrete. Through this they ran
telephone cables forming one of New York's main
lines of communication. Across the Gila River in
Arizona they constructed a catenary span 2373 feet
long. To bridge oceans, they developed radio telephony. They have built telephone lines over mountains, across deserts, through swamps.
Their resourcefulness in getting through, over or
under natural barriers makes possible telephone service that is practically world wide in reach.

BELL SYSTEM

University, the spring vacation has been
definitely set for the last week in March.
It seems to me that this innovation is
entirely detrimental to the student body.
In the past, the administrators of the
University have acted without giving serious thought to the desires of the students. This change is another of these
dictatorial acts. I am fairly certain that
the student body would much prefer to
have their vacation during Easter.
The administration has stated that the
reason for this change was to have the
second semester of the year divided into
two equal halves. They have said that
this would make the task of teaching a
course easier, as the instructor would not
have to revise his schedule to fit the
current date of Easter. Although I am
taking six courses, I must say that in
none of these does the date of Easter
have any effect upon the teaching of the
course.
The administration has also stated that
since we finish the scholastic year at a
very early date, we should have our
spring vacation as soon as possible. Although Columbia University starts its
summer vacation a full two weeks before
we do, it has its spring holiday during
Easter.
I think that the University would do
well to consider the desire of the students
as well as the whims of the faculty members when they are considering matters
of great importance to the student body.
A JUNIOR.

22 MEN OF 1932

SQUAD RETURNED
Practice Will Be Held Regularly During Spring
Vacation
The 1933 conception of the old
Indian game, lacrosse, will make its
debut here on Saturday, April 8,
when the Johns Hopkins lacrosse
team, 1932 Olympic champion, inaugurates its current season against
Washington College at Homewood
field.
Lacrosse, this year, will be played
on a field 30 yards shorter than last
season's and with teams of 10 men
instead of the usual 12 which engaged in the game previous to this
year. For this reason, the Black
and Blue practice sessions for the
past two weeks have been in the
nature of an experiment to determine what type of play will give the
strongest game in compliance with
the new rules.
Coach Working New Plays

Coach Van Orman and his staff,
feeling that many new angles of the
game will turn up from practical
experience in contests, plan intensive
drills so that all phases of the game
can be thoroughly tested and the
Hopkins stickmen instructed in
overcoming any handicaps that may
arise from the rules changes.
Twenty-two members of last
year's squad are out to make the
Blue Jay team again this year, in
addition to many promising freshmen. Because of this wealth of material available for the team, the
coaches plan to drill two full teams
into shape, which will share action
in the games.

Manager Harold Stein
made the announcement that he
has added Swarthmore and Duke
to the tennis team's schedule.
Swarthmore will be played away
April 13th and Duke will be encountered at Homewood May 4th.
This completes the campaign, which
includes 16 matches with many of
the strongest teams in the east.
Lindsay Helmholtz, a student in
the grad school, who has been a
member of the varsity tennis team
for the last 3 years, will assist Dr.
Silverman in coaching the team.

Denouncing the attitude of Republicans, Democrats and Socialists
on the question of race prejudice,
Emmet May, colored graduate of
Shaw College and Tennessee educator, last week presented his point
of view on the "Negro Question"
before members of the National
Student League.
May dramatically described in
his speech the story of the lynching of an innocent boy by an angry
mob of citizens in a southern town
where he was teaching. He said that
he was acquainted with the boy and
knew that the charges against him
had been "trumped up."

Banker," Sloan traced the conditions that had led to the present bank
holiday. He declared that both
state and national bank authorities
had been too lax in granting licenses to new banks. Accordingly,
banks had grown up which possessed no adequate capital or reserves, which were run by inexperienced and dishonest men and
which engaged in speculation and
unsound banking practices. When
the public lost confidence in these
banks, and the inevitable runs
started, the majority of such banking institutions could not meet the
demands of their depositors and
finally, to prevent the failure of
vast numbers of banks, a holiday
was declared.
From this experience, the banker
said, certain things have become
clear. First, the small "crossroads"
bank must go; second, all banks
should be brought under the Federal Reserve System; third, the supervision of these banks must
become more strict. He stated that
banks should fulfill only one main
function: that of keeping their depositors' money safe and available;
and all other activities, especially
those of a speculative nature, should
be forbidden. Strict reserve requirements should be set up, higher
than those today, and banks failing
to fulfill such requirements should
be fined or closed. The assets of all
banks, he declared, should be revalued after an examination every

ILLUSION:
A large packing case is exhibited on a raised platform. A young woman climbs into the box. Head,
hands and feet protrude, and are held by spectators while the magician takes a crosscut saw and,
with the help of an assistant, saws through the
center of the box and apparently through the woman.

EXPLANATION:
There are many explanations for this illusion. One
method of performing this illusion requires the
presence of two girls in the box. One girl curls up
in the left half of the box with her head and hands
protruding, giving the effect you see illustrated
above. The other girl is doubled up in the right
half of the box, with only her feet showing. Nobody
is sawed in half.

Travelling Actor,
Makes Clever Cut

Max Montor, On Carl Schurz
Foundation, Gives Masterpiece From Memory
Through the courtesy of the Carl
SchurzMemorial Foundation Hop-kins was favored with a Faust recitation by Max Montor last Monday
at Levering. Montor, a well known
German actor, is now traveling in
this country, reciting masterpieces
of the German and English stage.
His "Faust, Part One," which he
gave entirely from memory was very
ingeniously cut, reducing the enormous play to the extent of an hour
and a half, thus bringing out the
action very clearly. The Hall was
well filled with about 200 people
from Hopkins as well as from town,
who enjoyed the masterly rendering
of Goethe's greatest work.
